scientific_summary: Interpersonal trust strengthens through attachment-consistent behaviors, oxytocin-linked rituals, and consistent boundary work (Mikolajczak et al., 2010).

immediate.title: Anchor to a safe memory
instructions: Close your eyes and recall a moment you felt grounded with someone reliable.
Notice where the sense of safety lands in your body (chest, shoulders, hands).
Breathe slowly into that area for five cycles, repeating the phrase 'I am supported'.

evidence.source: Cozolino, The Neuroscience of Human Relationships, 2014
evidence.summary: Recalling secure attachment experiences reduces stress responses and increases trust signals.

immediate.title: Warm touch reset
instructions: Place a warm hand over your heart or hug yourself gently.
Spend three slow breaths focusing on the warmth and pressure.
Optional: if with a trusted person, exchange a 20-second hug to release oxytocin.

evidence.summary: Warm touch increases oxytocin release, strengthening trust and prosocial feelings.

immediate.title: Micro affirmation breath
instructions: On each inhale, silently say 'I can lean in'; on each exhale, say 'I am held'.
Repeat for six cycles while pressing thumb and forefinger together as an anchoring cue.
Recall one recent instance someone followed through for you.

evidence.summary: Brief loving-kindness phrases increase oxytocin-linked trust and calm.

short_term.title: Boundary affirmation
instructions: List one boundary that keeps you safe in relationships (e.g., time, tone, honesty).
Write a sentence about how you will communicate or uphold this boundary this week.
Visualize yourself stating it assertively and the outcome feeling respected.

evidence.source: American Psychological Association, Assertiveness Training Review, 2017
evidence.summary: Clear boundary setting increases perceived control and trust in relationships.

short_term.title: Gratitude micro-letter
instructions: Write a short note (or voice memo) thanking someone for a specific act of reliability.
Include details about how the act made you feel calm or supported.
Send it, or if not sending, read it aloud to reinforce the neural pathways of trust.

evidence.summary: Expressing gratitude strengthens interpersonal trust and connection.

short_term.title: Shared agenda planning
instructions: With a partner or teammate, list mutual goals for the week.
Assign clear owners and deadlines for each task.
Schedule a midpoint check-in to review progress.

evidence.summary: Clear role agreements and follow-through strengthen cognitive trust.

long_term.title: Weekly trust ritual
instructions: Schedule a recurring check-in with a trusted partner/friend to share wins and worries.
Use active listening (reflect back what you heard) for at least five minutes each.
Close by naming one appreciative statement about the relationship.

evidence.source: Gottman & Silver, The Seven Principles for Making Marriage Work, 2015
evidence.summary: Regular appreciation and check-ins build trust and emotional bank accounts.

long_term.title: Self-trust journal
instructions: Document three decisions you made this week and how you honored your needs.
Note any moments where you overrode your intuition and what you learned.
Set one micro-intention for self-trust in the coming days (e.g., pausing before saying yes).

evidence.summary: Self-trust practices rooted in self-compassion improve emotional resilience and relationship trust.

long_term.title: Repair playbook
instructions: Reflect on a past rupture that was repaired well and extract the steps used.
Outline a three-step repair protocol (acknowledge, empathize, plan) for future conflicts.
Share the playbook with trusted people so expectations are aligned.

evidence.source: Gottman & Levenson, Journal of Consulting and Clinical Psychology, 1992
evidence.summary: Couples who practice explicit repair scripts maintain higher trust after conflict.

friend_support.title: Consistency check
instructions: Ask your friend which supportive behaviors help them feel secure (updates, punctuality).
Brainstorm how you can deliver one of those behaviors this week.
Confirm how they will let you know if needs shift.

evidence.summary: Responsive adjustments to partner cues foster interpersonal trust.

friend_support.title: Affirm their reliability story
instructions: Invite your friend to share a time they showed up for someone else.
Reflect the character strengths you heard (steadfast, thoughtful).
Encourage them to keep a note of these stories for moments of doubt.

evidence.source: Lambert & Fincham, Journal of Positive Psychology, 2011
evidence.summary: Reminding partners of past reliability increases perceived trustworthiness.

self_repair.title: Repair after a trust breach
instructions: Describe the breach factually ("I missed the deadline I promised").
Acknowledge the emotional impact and what it cost the other person.
Offer restitution and a prevention plan with specific checkpoints.

evidence.source: Kim et al., Academy of Management Journal, 2004
evidence.summary: Comprehensive apologies with restitution restore trust more effectively than simple sorrys.

self_repair.title: Rebuild self-trust routine
instructions: List two commitments you have to yourself that were broken (rest, boundaries).
Plan a realistic action to fulfill each within the next week.
Track completion and note how honoring your needs supports trusting others.

evidence.source: Lazarus & Folkman, Stress, Appraisal, and Coping, 1984
evidence.summary: Consistent self-care commitments increase perceived self-efficacy and relational trust.
